text.front:
THE JOURNAL OF BIOLOGICAL CHEMISTRY
0 1989 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc
Vol. 264, No. 2, Issue of January 15, pp. 872-883,1989
Printed in U S. A.
Structures of Neutral 0-Linked Polylactosaminoglycans on Human
Skim Milk Mucins
A NOVEL TYPE OF LINEARLY EXTENDED POLY-N-ACETYLLACTOSAMINE BACKBONES WITH
Galp( 1-4)GlcNAcp(1-6) REPEATING UNITS*
(Received for publication, May 5, 1988)
Franz-Georg Hanisch and Gerhard Uhlenbruck
From the Department of Immurwbiology, Medical University Clinic I of Cologne, Kerpener Strasse 15,
0-5000 Cologne 41, Federal Republic of Germany
Jasna Peter-Katalinic and Heinz Egge
From the Institute of Physiological Chemistry, University of Bonn, Nussallee 11, 0-5300 Bonn 1, Federal Republic of Germany
Janusz Dabrowski and Ursula Dabrowski
From the Max Planck Institute of Medical Research, Jahnstrasse 29,0-6900 Heidelberg, Federal Republic of Germany
0-Linked oligosaccharides were isolated from hu-
man skim milk mucins and from mucin-derived gly-
copeptides by reductive &elimination. The released
alditols were fractionated by DEAE-Sephadex chro-
matography and purified by high performance liquid
chromatography on primarj. amine bonded phase. The
structures of the major neutral oligosaccharide alditols
could be established by fast atom bombardment and
electron impact mass spectrometry,
combined with
methylation analysis, 500-MHz 'H nuclear magnetic
resonance spectroscopy, and endo-&galactosidase
(from Bacteroides frugilis, EC 3.2.1.103) digestion
(where n = 0-3):
GaW 1 ,
3)
GalNAc-ol
Galfl(1-3/4)GlcNAcfl (1
[\ 6)Galfl(l-4)GlcNAcfl ] ,(I 7)
Major 0-glycosidically linked oligosaccharides
on
skim milk mucins are of the Galj3(1-3)[GlcNAcfl(1-6)]
GalNAc core type 2 and exhibit linearly extended
backbone chains of the poly N-acetyllactosamine type
comprizing up to at least four repeating units, which
are linked by the hitherto unknown sequence GlcNAc-
j3(1-6) Gal rather than GlcNAcj3(1-3)Gal. A consid-
erable portion of neutral alditols is represented by
branched isomers of the linear species, which are dis-
tinguished by their content of 3,6-disubstituted galac-
tose and their partial resistance to endo-8-galactosid-
ase digestion.
text.body:
Oligosaccharides of the polylactosamine type have been
identified on glycoproteins and glycolipids expressing various
developmental and tumor-associated antigens (1, 2). On gly-
text.front:
* This investigation was supported by Deutsche Forschungsge-
meinschaft Grant Uh 8/14-2 and by the Fritz Thyssen Stiftung (to
J. D. and U. D.). The costs of publication of this article were defrayed
in part by the payment of page charges. This article must therefore
be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.S.C.
Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
text.body:
coproteins these oligosaccharides are linked to
a (Man)a
(GlcNAc)Z1 core common to N-glycans and exhibit repetitive
Galpl-4GlcNAcpl-3 sequences comprizing up to six or more
units. Polyglycosyl chains (3) or polylactosaminoglycans (4)
have been described to occur on erythrocytes, (1,3) teratocar-
cinoma cells ( 5 ) , granulocytes (6), and pheochromocytoma
cells (7). Recently, immunochemical and enzymatic evidence
has been obtained for the occurrence of 0-glycosidically linked
polylactosaminoglycans on human leucocyte common antigen
(8).
This contribution presents chemical evidence for 0-linked
polylactosaminoglycans as major components of secreted mu-
cins in the fraction of human milk caseins. These mucins
have been described in a preceding paper to express tumor-
associated antigens Ca 19-9 and Ca 125 and to carry a series
of monosialylated oligosaccharides (9).
Similar mucin-type
glycoproteins have been demonstrated on a variety of human
(10) and animal mammary carcinoma cells (11). Expression
of these high molecular weight glycoproteins on plasma mem-
branes has been reported to be associated with the metastatic
phenotype of carcinoma cells (11), pointing to a possible
functional involvement of mucins in the metastatic process.
EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES~
RESULTS
Isolation of Mucins and Mucin-derived Glycopeptides
Purification of mucins contained in the fraction of caseins
and their chemical and physicochemical characterization have
been described in a preceding paper (9). Structural informa-
text.note:
l The abbreviations used are: GlcNAc, N-acetylglucosamine; Fuc,
fucose; GalNAc, N-acetylgalactosamine; FAB-MS, fast atom bom-
bardment mass spectrometry; EI-MS, electron impact mass spec-
trometry; HPLC, high performance liquid chromatography; Hex,
hexose; HexNAc, N-acetylhexosamine; 'H NMR, proton nuclear mag-
netic resonance; D l andD2, one-dimensional and two-dimensional;
COSY, two-dimensional correlated spectroscopy.
* Portions of this paper (including "Experimental Procedures,"
Tables 1-3, and 7, and additional references 1-6) are presented in
miniprint at the end of this paper. Miniprint is easily read with the
aid of a standard magnifying glass. Full size photocopies are included
in the microfilm edition of the Journal that is
available from Waverly
Press.

Unbranched Polylactosamino-0-glycans o n
H u m a n
Milk Mucins
text.body:
tion of relevance with regard to the present contribution came
from compositional analyses suggesting that the high molec-
ular weight glycoproteins, excluded from Sephacryl S400 in
the presence of 4 M guanidinium chloride and designated as
mucins, were actually devoid of D-mannOSe. The total yield
of mucins calculated for 1 liter of human milk was 70 mg.
Isolation of mucin-derived glycopeptides (250 mg) from a
Pronase digest of crude human casein was achieved by phenol,
6 M urea extraction. The crude glycopeptide mixture was
further fractionated by gel exclusion chromatography on Bio-
Gel P-30 as shown in Fig. 1. Monosaccharide analyses of
fractions A-D revealed only traces of D-mannose on large
glycopeptides (fraction A), whereas a considerable content of
D-mannose was measured in fractions C and D indicating N -
glycan carrying glycopeptides, which may have originated
from contaminating whey glycoproteins (Table 1). Large gly-
copeptides in fraction A (50 mg) or mucins were subjected to
alkaline borohydride treatment.

FIG. 1. Gel exclusion chromatography of mucin (a) and mu-
cin-derived glycopeptides (b) on Sephacryl S400 (a) or Bio-
Gel P-30 (b). a, phenol/saline-extracted glycoproteins from skim
milk (1 g) were applied onto a column of Sephacryl S400 (2.5 X 100
ern) equilibrated and run in 4 M guanidinium chloride, 1 mM sodium
phosphate, pH 7.0, 1 mM Nag-EDTA. Elution was performed with a
flow rate of 24 rnI/h. 4-ml fractions were collected and analyzed
spectrophotometrically at 280 nm. b, phenol/urea-extractedglycopep-
tides from milk caseins (30 mg) were applied onto a column of Bio-
Gel P-30 (2.2 X 80 cm) equilibrated and run in 0.01 M pyridine
acetate, pH 5.0. Elution was performed with a flow rate of 24 ml/h
and 3-ml fractions were collected. Fractions were analyzed by the
thiobarbituric acid method for their content of sialic acid (absorbance
at 549 nm, 0 ) or by enzyme immunoassay of 5 0 -~l aliquots using
monoclonal antibodies 115C2 (absorbance at 405 nm, 0) or Leu M1
(absorbance at.405 nm, . . . .).
Immunochemical Characterization of Carbohydrate Antigens
Expressed on Mucins or Mucin-derived Glycopeptides
Antigen patterns on mucins and mucin-derived glycopep-
tides were analyzed using a series of monoclonal antibodies
with defined carbohydrate epitopes in enzyme assays or radio-
immunoassays (Table 2). Fractionation of Pronase-stable gly-
copeptides on Bio-Gel P-30 was registered by measuring an-
tigen activities Le"-X or X, respectively:
GalP(1-3)GlcNAcfl(l-3)Gal~(1-4)GlcNAc
4
3
1
1
Fuca
Fuca
I
I
defined by monoclonal antibody 115 C2, and
Galfl(1-4)GlcNAc
3
I
1
Fuca
defined by monoclonal antibody Leu M1.
The activity profiles in Fig. 1 suggest that both isomeric
terminal sequences are coexpressed and restricted to large
glycopeptides contained in fraction A. Le*-X distribution on
large and smaller-sized glycopeptides may represent 0-glycan
elution, since this hybrid of type 1-and type 2-based struc-
tures has never been found to occur on N-glycans but is a
regular constituent of secreted mucins and mucin-derived
oligosaccharide alditols3 (19). Concerning the latter, 2 pg of
fractions MM-MS or MM-DS (see "Experimental Proce-
dures") compared with 10 pg of fraction MM-N were able to
inhibit 50% of 115 C2 binding in enzyme immunoassay.
Milk mucins and mucin-derived glycopeptides, moreover,
exhibit antigen activities T (defined by antibody 49H8), H2
(defined by antibody A46-B/B10), sialyl-Le" (defined by an-
tibody NS 19-9) and Lea, Leb (defined by antibodies Le" 01 or
Leb 01, respectively). Antigen sialyl dimeric X (defined
by
monoclonal antibody FH6) was not detectable on mucin-0-
glycans.
Human breast carcinoma-associated antigens
MCA (20)
(>50 units/mg) and Ca 15-3 (21) (230 units/mg) are coex-
pressed on skim milk mucins together with the previously
detected tumor markers Ca 19-9 and Ca 125 (9).
Neutral Oligosaccharides from Milk Mucins and Mucin-
derived, Large Glycopeptides
0-glycan liberation from mucins or glycopeptides by alka-
line reductive treatment provided a mixture of oligosaccharide
alditols, which was fractionated by ion-exchange chromatog-
raphy on DEAE-Sephadex A25 followed by high performance
liquid chromatography on primary amine bonded phase (Fig.
2). Independent of the source, neutral alditols representing
-50% of total carbohydrates released from large glycopeptides
or mucins (20-30 mg) comprized a t least 30 different species
ranging in size from 2 to 16 monosaccharides. Major compo-
nents were nonfucosylated species resistant to mild trichlo-
roacetic acid treatment, which eluted in fractions MM-N4,
MM-N6, MM-N8, MM-N10, and MM-Nl2. As judged from
the HPLC profiles the molar proportions estimated for each
component contained in the fraction of neutral alditols were
similar for mucin-and glycopeptide-derived oligosaccharides
(Table 3 and Fig. 2).
F.-G. Hanisch and G. Uhlenbruck, unpublished results.

Structural Analysis of Oligosaccharide Alditols
The freeze-dried saccharide alditols from each HPLC frac-
tion were divided into three portions. Part of the saccharide
alditols was permethylated and subjected to FAB-or EI-mass
spectrometry followed by methylation analysis. Another por-
tion was digested with endo-/3-galactosidase prior to per-
acetylation of the reaction products and FAB-MS analysis. A
third portion of underivatized alditols was used for 'H NMR
analysis. Since the structures of the major components in
each fraction turned out to be identical for the mucin-and
glycopeptide-derived alditols, but on the other hand, a consid-
erable heterogeneity of minor components became evident
particularly for the glycopeptide derived fractions, the pre-
sented structural data are confined to mucin-derived O-gly-
cans.
Fraction MM-Ri4-FAB-mass spectrometry of permethyl-
ated oligosaccharide alditols in fraction MM-N4 revealed the
presence of one major species being represented by the pseu-
domolecular ion M + H at m/z 961 (Table 4). In accordance
with data from a monosaccharide analysis (Table l), this
pseudomolecular ion corresponds to a tetrasaccharide com-
posed of GalzGlcNAcGalNAc-01. Sequence analysis by EI-
mass spectrometry suggested the structural elements Hex-
HexNAc (represented at m/z 219, 464) and Hex-HexNAc-ol

The branching pattern at the alditol terminus is also cor-
roborated by formation of 1,4,5-tri-O-methyl-N-methylacet-
amido-2-deoxygalactitol in methylation analysis (Table 6),
which confirms a substitution of the GalNAc-ol residue in
positions 0-3 and 0-6. The partially methylated GlcNAc
derivative 3,6-di-O-methyl-N-methylacetamid0-2-deoxy-
glucitol and the fragment ions registered in EI-mass spectrom-
etry at m/z 182 (22) and 432 (23) are indicative of a 4-
substituted hexosamine. The above presented results may be
summarized in the following structure model for the major

The secondary fragments at m/z 432 (464-methanol) and
228 (464-hexose1, which are formed by preferential elimina-
tion of the 0-3-linked HexNAc substituent (23), could point
to the presence of two molecular species with isomeric ter-
minal sequences Hex(1-4)HexNAc and Hex( 1-3)HexNAc,
respectively. Methylation analysis confirmed the presence of
both GlcNAc substitution isomers 3,6-di-O-methyl-N-meth-
ylacetamido-2-deoxyglucitol and 4,6-di-O-methyl-N-methyl-
acetamido-2-deoxyglucitol (Table 6). Branching at the ter-
minal alditol is revealed by formation of 1,4,5-tri-O-methyl-
N-methylacetamido-2-deoxygalactitol and by the absence of
the primary fragment ion at m/z 276 in the El-mass spectrum.
6-Mono-0-substitution of internal galactose is indicated by
2,3,4-tri-O-methy1-1,5,6-tri-O-acetyl galactitol formed on
methylation analysis as the only tri-0-acetylated hexitol (Ta-
ble 6 and Fig. 6). Approximately 30% of the internal galactose
was represented by 2,4-di-O-methyl galactitol acetate, point-
ing to the occurrence of a branch point in a second major
alditol species, which may also contain an incomplete side
chain terminating in nonreducing GlcNAc (Table 6). Based
on the above-presented combined data, the primary structure
of the major saccharide alditol in MM-N6 is proposed as:
Gal(1,
3)
Gal(l-3/4)GlcNAc(l,
6)
GalNAc-ol
G)Gal(l-4)GlcNAc(l'
Fraction MM-N8"The major oligosaccharide alditol in
permethylated fraction MM-N8 is characterized by the pseu-
domolecular ions M + H at m/z 1859 and M + Na at mlz
1881 in FAB-mass spectrometry (Fig. 2; and Table 4) and
with reference to a monosaccharide analysis is calculated to
have the composition Ga14GlcNAc3GalNAc-01. Fragmentation
of the oligosaccharide alditol revealed the primary ion series
at m/z 464, 913, and 1362, suggesting the presence of three
repetitive, linearly linked Hex-HexNAc units (Fig. 3b). Lin-
earity of the hexasaccharide sequence of one of the major
species is corroborated by a set of corresponding fragments
obtained on endo-P-galactosidase digestion and peracetylation
of the reaction mixture: Hex3HexNAct and (HexHexNAcd-
01 or HexnHexNAc and (HexzHexNAc&ol (Table 5 ) . A con-
siderable portion of alditols in M"N8
was resistant to en-
zymatic cleavage.
The intense fragment ions registered at m/z 432 (464-
methanol) and 228 (464-hexose) are presumably derived by
elimination of 03-linked substituents from the penultimate
GlcNAc (23) and may be interpreted in terms of a heteroge-
neity with respect to the substitution pattern of this residue.
This heterogeneity becomes also obvious on methylation
analysis, which revealed a formation of isomeric GlcNAc

derivatives 3,6 di-0-methyl-N-methylacetamido-2-deoxyglu-
citol and 4,6 di-0-methyl-N-methylacetamido-2-deoxyglucitol
in approximate molar proportions 311. The core structure of
the saccharide could be deduced from the partially methylated
GalNAc-ol derivative 1,4,5-tri-0-methyl-N-methylacetam-
ido-2-deoxygalactitol (Table 6). Approximately 60% of inter-
nal galactose residues is represented by the 6-mono-0-substi-
tuted derivative, and the remainder, by 3,6-di-O-substituted
galactose. This suggests that a considerable portion of fraction
MM-N8 alditols is branched. The presented data can be
summarized in the tentative structural model postulated for
the major component in fraction MM-N8 (refer also to 'H
NMR data in Table 8).

STRUCTURE^
There is only a limited number of structural alternatives of
the linear species (Structure 1) in MM-N8. Only one (Struc-
ture 2 ) partially fits the data from FAB-MS (primary frag-
ment ions at m/z 464 and 1362), methylation analysis (3,6 di-
0-substituted galactose), and endo-&galactosidase digestion
(hydrolytic resistance) and is in accordance with 'H chemical
text.note: Unbranched Polylactosamino-0-glycans on Human Milk Mucins
text.body:
shifts measured in NMR spectroscopy (Table 8).
Gal(1,
3)
Gal(l-4)GlcNAc(l 2 )
Gal(l-3/4)GlcNAc(l,
GalNAc-ol
6)
Gal(l-B/4)GlcNAc(l
/3'
STRUCTURE 2
Fraction MM-NIO-FAB-mass spectrometry of this per-
methylated fraction revealed the presence of three molecular
species represented by the respective pseudomolecular ions M
+ H at m/z 2308, 2033, and 2207, respectively (Fig. 3c and
Table 4). Based on mass increment calculation and monomer
analysis, the major component of this fraction is a decasac-
charide alditol composed of Ga16GlcNAc4GalNAc-ol (Table
1). Sequence analysis revealed a series of primary fragments
at m/z 464, 913, 1362, and 1811 which are compatible with a
linear octasaccharide sequence consisting of repetitive Hex-
HexNAc units (Fig. 3c). A branch point within this sequence
can be excluded at least for a major portion of the nonfuco-

Also in this fraction, approximately 50% of the alditols was
found to be resistant to endo-@-galactosidase digestion.
Alditol fragmentation in EI-mass spectrometry giving rise
to ions at m/z 378 and 422 (refer to MM-N4) and data from
methylation analysis (Table 6) confirmed a branched core
structure identical with that established for oligosaccharide
alditols in fractions MM-N4, MM-N6, and MM-N8. As pre-
viously observed for the hexa-and octasaccharides in fractions
MM-N6 or MM-N8, a heterogeneity with respect to the
substitution of subterminal GlcNAc became also evident for
the decasaccharide on methylation analysis (Table 6) com-
bined with analysis of secondary fragments (m/z 228, 432
presumably derived from the ion at m/z 464) formed on FAB-
mass spectrometry (Fig. 3c). 6-Mono-0-substituted and 3,6-
di-0-substituted galactose were represented by the respective
partially methylated alditol acetates in the approximate molar
proportions 2/1, indicating the presence of branched isomers.

Both structures are expected to be susceptible to endo-@-
galactosidase digestion at internal galactose residues indicated
by arrows, but should not yield hydrolytic fragments
HexaHexNAc2 and (Hex2HexNAc3)-ol due to the established
enzymatic resistance of disubstituted galactose residues (24).
The minor components of fraction MM-N10 represent h-
cosylated species containing one (M + H at m/z 2033) or two
(M + H at m/z 2207) deoxyhexose residues and being derived
from an octasaccharide alditol of the composition GaLGlc-
NAc3GalNAc-01 (Table 4 and Fig. 3c).
Fractions MM-N7, -9, -11, -12, -13, and -14-These frac-
tions represent heterogeneous mixtures of fucosylated and
nonfucosylated species as may be inferred from the pseudo-
molecular ions presented in Table 4. Although conclusive data
on the component alditols could not be obtained and definite
structural assignments were impossible, some of their struc-
tural.aspects may be summarized.
The nonfucosylated species in these fractions comprize up
to 16 monosaccharide units, which on the basis of composi-
tional analyses and FAB-MS fragmentation (homologous se-
ries of intense signals differing by the mass increment of
text.note:
Unbranched Polylactosamino-0-glycans on
Human
Milk Mucins
text.body:
HexHexNAc) are presumably arranged in polylactosamine-
type chains.
Special attention should be focused on the fucosylated
species contained in fractions MM-N7
to MM-N14 with
respect to their fucosylation patterns (Table 7). Since the
alditols had been isolated from pooled milk samples of indi-
viduals with undefined secretory status and Lewis blood
groups, substitution of terminal Gal@(l-3/4)GlcNAc should
reflect the genetic distribution of Se and Le genes. Accord-
ingly, the primary fragment ion at m/z 638, detected in
fractions MM-N9 to MM-N14, represents terminal trisaccha-
ride dHexHexHexNAc, a major portion being assumed to
contain the structural element Fuca(l-2)Gal, as normally
found in secretors.
Pseudomolecular ions and primary fragment ions in FAB-
MS corroborated the presence of mono-, di-, and trifuco-
sylated oligosaccharide alditols (Tables 4 and 7). Based on
the respective series of primary fragment ions, the possible
sites of fucosylation along the polylactosamine chain are
shown in Table 7.
'H NMR Spectroscopy
Fractions MM-N4, -N6, and -N8 were analyzed by one-
111 1
h
h
Vlll 1
and two-dimensional 'H NMR spectroscopy at 500 MHz (Fig.
7 and Table 8). The GalNAc-01-1 resonances for these three
fractions are almost identical and differ only little from those
assigned by Mutsaers et al. (25) for a GalNAc-ol residue
having the same proximal environment. The 2 terminal Gal
residues linked to different aglycons show slightly different
Hl-H2-H3-H4 connectivity paths in the two-dimensional
spectrum of MM-N4. All Gal and GlcNAc residues have a 0
configuration, as follows from their 3J1,2 coupling constants
The substitution patterns of Gal and GlcNAc residues in
MM-N6 and -N8 were elucidated with the aid of the previ-
ously established regularities concerning glycosylation-in-
duced shifts. It was observed (26, 27) that glycosylation in-
duces marked downfield shifts for the protons at the substi-
tution site and at both vicinal sites, but leaves other proton
resonances much less, or not at all, affected. This was recently
confirmed by the data reported by Baumann et al. (28).
Consequently, since the chemical shifts of Gal-I11 H2, H3,
and H4 are practically identical for MM-N4, -N6, and -N8,
these protons are obviously located at hydroxylated carbons,
which means that C6 must be glycosylated (the same refers
to Gal-V of MM-N8). However, as pointed out in the discus-
of 7.5-9.5 HZ.
FIG. 7. The 500-MHz 'H NMR
spectra of the oligosaccharide aldi-
to1 MM-N4. a, partial one-dimensional
spectrum. Arabic numerak denote the

mula in Table 8). b, 'H shift-autocorre-

scripts and subscripts refer to connectiv-
ities between two coupled protons. The

superscript should be read on the hori-
zontal scale (up) and the shift of the
proton marked with a subscript is de-
fined by the vertical scale (ul). To avoid
crowding, only one cross-peak from each
pair is labeled, either above or below the
diagonal.

text.note: Unbranched Polylactosamino-O-glycans on Human Milk Mucins
text.body:
sion of the data on MS and methylation analysis, the samples
were heterogeneous, and the 2,4-di-O-methyl galactitol found
for both MM-N6 and -N8 (Table 6) requires that about 10%
of Gal residues present in the samples are 3,6-diglycosylated.
This, in turn, would require that Gal H4 signal be shifted
from the 3.92 ppm into the 4.13-4.15 ppm region, where H4
resonances of 3,6-diglycosylated Gal residues have been found
for oligosaccharides obtained from human
milk (29) and
erythrocytes (30) and that Gal H3 signal be shifted to 3.72
ppm, as shown in Ref. 29. As a matter of fact, a very weak
cross-peak at 4.14/3.73 ppm was found in the COSY spectrum
of MM-N6, but in that of MM-N8, the corresponding contour
was barely above the noise level. Due to the small amount of
the substances investigated (see "Experimental Procedures"),
it is not unexpected that the proof of 10% of a constituent of
a microheterogeneous system may be problematic.
Concerning the 3 uersus 4 linkage to a GlcNAc residue, it
is the H2 resonance which is diagnostic, since in the former
case it should be shifted toward lower field due to the neigh-
borhood of the glycosylated C3. In the COSY spectrum of
MM-N6 (Table 8), one of the two GlcNAc H2 resonances is
practically identical with that found for MM-N4 (3.75 uersus
3.760 ppm), whereas the other one is shifted
by 0.15 ppm
toward lower field (to 3.90 ppm), pointing to a 1-3 terminal
linkage. Again, this is confirmed by the data on several human
milk oligosaccharides (29), whose GlcNAc H2 resonances were
found a t 3.76 and 3.88-3.90 ppm for the Galp(1-4)GlcNAc
and Galp( l-3)GlcNAc fragments, respectively, and also by
the results obtained for glycopeptides derived from calf fe-
tuin, whose corresponding GlcNAc H2 chemical shifts were
3.79 uersus 3.89 ppm (27). The GlcNAc H2/H1 correlations
of MM-N6 were found at almost identical shifts for MM-N8,
but, in addition, the
high field H2 resonance exhibited a
correlation to a new H 1 resonance (3.757/4.589 ppm) of one
proton intensity, thus showing that the molecule contains one
more internal Galp(1-4)GlcNAc disaccharide unit. The above
analysis applies to the main component of each of the three
fractions investigated. However, due to the heterogeneity of
the samples, a number of minor NMR signals occur along
with those referring to the dominant component. One
of these
weak signals in the one-dimensional spectrum of MM-N6 (at
4.605 ppm; not mentioned in Table 8) is probably due to a
-25% admixture of molecules containing a terminal Galp
(l-4)GlcNAc disaccharide fragment. In the two-dimensional
spectrum, a H1/H2 cross-peak at 4.57/3.67 ppm points to
some admixture of species containing terminal GlcNAc resi-
dues.
DISCUSSION
This study presents structural evidence for the organ char-
acteristic expression of highly clustered O-glycosidically
linked polylactosaminoglycans on mucins of human skim
milk. These mucins had
previously been demonstrated to
carry oncofetal carbohydrate antigens Ca 19-9 and Ca 125 (9)
and are presumed to be related antigenically and structurally
to a high molecular weight membrane glycoprotein isolated
from human milk fat globules3 (31). Similar mucin-like gly-
coproteins on human milk fat globule membranes have been
reported by Shimizu and Yamaguchi (32), Ormerod et at. (33),
and Krohn et al. (34), who also demonstrated an antigenic
relationship to secreted
mucins or high molecular weight
glycoproteins of skim milk (33, 34). As human milk fat glob-
ular membranes originate from the apical cell membrane of
milk-secreting cells, these soluble mucins of skim milk may
serve as a model for studies on organ-characteristic O-glycan
structure and biosynthesis in mammary epithelial cells.
The mucins of human skim milk have previously been
shown to precipitate with the casein fraction at pH 4.6 and
to contain -70% of mannose-free, alkali-labile carbohydrates
(9). Large glycopeptides with clustered
O-glycans could be
separated from a Pronase digest of crude caseins exhibiting
the same pattern of carbohydrate antigens and reductively
cleaved oligosaccharide alditols as skim milk mucins. The 0-
glycans characterized in this study are definitely not derived
from K-casein, as may be argued, since this highly glycosylated
glycoprotein of human casein could be separated from the
mucins according to its size (9) and has been demonstrated
to be devoid of antigenic activities Ca 19-9, Ca 125, and Ca
15-3 (9).3 Moreover, O-glycans of human K-casein have been
studied by JollGs and co-workers (35, 3G), who could charac-
terize a series of smaller-sized oligosaccharides. Despite this,
there is evidently also no relation to secretory immunoglob-
ulin A contained in human whey (37, 38) or to proteoglycans
secreted by mammary epithelial cells (39). On the other hand,
O-glycans with repetitive lactosamine exceeding 3 units,
which accordingly may be designated as polylactosaminogly-
cans, have not been described so far on a chemical basis,
whether in human milk nor in any other source of human or
animal origin. Childs et at. (8), however, have demonstrated
polylactosamino-O-glycans to occur on human leucocyte com-
mon antigen, and Fukuda et al. (40) were able to chemically
characterize minor O-linked oligosaccharides with repetitive
lactosamine (up to 3 units) on normal human granulocytes.
In a recent publication Wu et al. (41) described a sulfated
polysaccharide of high molecular weight
O-glycosidically
linked to an ovarian cyst glycoprotein, which proved to be
related to highly branched polylactosamines.
The unique structural aspects of major polylactosamino-0-
glycans on skim milk mucins may be summarized as follows:
1) the carbohydrate chains
comprize up to 16 (or more)
monosaccharide units; 2) the core structures are of the com-
mon type 2 Gal~(l-3)[GlcNAc~(l-6)]GalNAc; 3) the polylac-
tosamine sequence of major species is unbranched; 4) the
repetitive N-acetyllactosamine units are linearly linked via
0 -6 of the galactose residues; and 5 ) another major portion of
polylactosamine sequences is branched via 3,6 di-O-substi-
tuted galactose.
The structural aspects stated
in points 3 and 4 are of
considerable interest with respect to the biosynthesis and
immunochemistry of polylactosamine-type carbohydrates. As
has been pointed out by Schachter (42), the known p6 GlcNAc
transferases responsible for synthesis of mucin core types 2
and 4 and the branch point of the blood group I determinant
require an 0-3 substitution of their target sugar. Taking this
into account, the P3GlcNAc transferase ("extension enzyme")
would have to act before the P6-GlcNAc transferase ("branch-
ing enzyme") (43).
Accordingly, unbranched carbohydrate
chains of the polylactosamine type, as described in the present
paper, exhibiting 6-mono-0-substitution of internal galactose
residues are hardly to be expected as regular biosynthetic
products, if the "3 before 6 rule" is of general validity. Core
oligosaccharides with the
common structural element
GlcNAcp( l-G)GalNAc-ol have been described recently to oc-
cur on human glycoproteins from meconium, K-casein, and
seminal plasma (44,35, 45) pointing to the possible existence
of a p6GlcNAc transferase in human tissues, which is inde-
pendent from 0 -3 substitution of its target sugars GalNAc or
Gal, respectively.
Cold agglutinins of the anti-I,i family have been demon-
strated to define polylactosamine sequences with
branched
(I-antigen) or linearly extented backbones (i-antigen) (46).
Reactivity of anti-I or anti-i antibodies with the novel type of
backbone structure exhibiting unbranched polylactosamine
sequences with a structural element of branched chains re-
text.note:
Unbranched Polylactosarnino-0-glycans on
Human
Milk
Mucins
text.body:
mains to be investigated.
A comparison of the major oligosaccharides found on mu-
cins from seminal plasma and skim milk reveals that the
former are represented by short carbohydrate chains (di-to
hexasaccharides) with prominent fucosylated or sialylated
species (45, 47) (Fig. 5 ) . This is in accordance with the high
activities of fucosykransferases and, to a lesser extent, of
sialyltransferases, measured in human seminal plasma (48),
which block chain elongation mainly on the tetrasaccharide
level. Milk mucin-producing cells on the other hand probably
exhibit high activities of a P6-GlcNAc transferase, thus pro-
ducing long carbohydrate chains of the polylactosamine type,
which may later become fucosylated or sialylated to a minor
extent.
Several biological functions of these polylactosamine-ex-
pressing mucins in human milk may be postulated, particu-
larly a protective role within the digestive tract of the newborn
infants. Mucins have been reported to stimulate lysozyme
activity (49), to enhance the growth of Bifidus flora in the
intestine (49), and to bind pathogenic microorganisms via
their surface l e c t i n~.~
Coexpression of human cancer antigens MCA (20) and Ca
15-3 (21) on skim milk mucins of lactating women and their
detection in the sera of patients suffering from metastatic
breast carcinoma suggests that the respective carbohydrate
sequences belong to the family of oncodevelopmental antigens
and that they may be located on members of the mucin-0-
glycan series characterized in this study. A possible functional
role of 1,i-active polylactosamine-0-glycans on skim milk
mucins with regard to the metastatic process of epithelial
mammary tumors directed to the human liver is currently
under investigation.
text.div:
Acknowledgments-We are obliged to Prof. Dr. A. Bolte, University
Clinic of Gynecology and Obstetrics, Cologne, for providing the
samples of human milk, Prof. Dr. M. Donike and Dr. W. Schantzer
for kind support by gas-liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry,
and G. Stellbrinck and C. Bottinger for their skillful technical assist-
ance.
